claim: Antarctica has a lot of problems relating to homelessness.

supporting.text: Antarctica has no permanent human population, making homelessness irrelevant.

attacks.text: Antarctica has no permanent human population, making homelessness irrelevant.
Scientific research stations in Antarctica have temporary residents who could face housing instability.
Housing instability in research stations is managed by strict protocols, not comparable to conventional homelessness.
Climate change may force migration to Antarctica, creating future homelessness concerns.
Current international treaties prohibit large-scale human settlement in Antarctica, making migration unlikely.

supporting.text: The continent is governed by international treaties that prohibit permanent settlements.

attacks.text: The continent is governed by international treaties that prohibit permanent settlements.
Despite treaties, illegal or temporary settlements could still lead to homelessness issues.
Enforcement of treaties is strict, making illegal settlements highly unlikely.
Scientific research stations have transient populations that may face housing instability.
Research stations provide structured accommodations, minimizing housing instability.

supporting.text: Extreme environmental conditions make long-term human habitation without infrastructure impossible.

attacks.text: Extreme environmental conditions make long-term human habitation without infrastructure impossible.
Scientific research stations demonstrate that with proper infrastructure, humans can live in Antarctica long-term.
Research stations are highly specialized and not comparable to general habitation, reinforcing the difficulty of homelessness in Antarctica.
Historical expeditions like those of Shackleton show that survival is possible even without modern infrastructure.
Such expeditions had extremely high mortality rates, proving the unsustainability of homelessness in Antarctica.

supporting.text: Research stations in Antarctica are temporary and house only scientists and support staff.

attacks.text: Research stations in Antarctica are temporary and house only scientists and support staff.
Some research stations may have unofficial or transient visitors who are not formally part of the scientific teams.
Even if unofficial visitors exist, they are not homeless as they have temporary shelter within the stations.
Historical records show instances of stranded explorers or adventurers who lacked formal housing in Antarctica.
These instances are extremely rare and do not constitute a systemic homelessness problem.

supporting.text: Homelessness requires a societal structure, which does not exist in Antarctica.

attacks.text: Homelessness requires a societal structure, which does not exist in Antarctica.
Research stations in Antarctica have temporary populations, which could experience homelessness if support systems fail.
The definition of homelessness includes lack of shelter, which could technically apply to stranded individuals in Antarctica regardless of societal structure.
Antarctica's extreme environment makes sustained human habitation without institutional support impossible, thus homelessness is a non-issue.
